projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

"For many centuries afte after Britain became an island" the

p.l: curtain woven of innumerable tree tops." On those matted
boughs innumerable birds sang; but their song was only heard
by a few skin clad hunters in the lcearings clearings . Did the desire
to sing come to one of those huntsmen because he heard the
birds sing, and so rested his axe against the tree for a
moment? But the tree had to be felled; and a hut made
from its branches before the human voice sang too.

p.l: The voice that broke the sielnce silence of the forests was
the voice of Anon. Some one heard the song and re embered remembered it
for it was later wrteen written down, beautifully on parchment.
Thus the singer had his audience, but the audience was so
little interested in his name that he never thought to give
it. For the audience was itself the singer; Terly terlow"
they sand; and "By, by lullay" filling in the pauses,
helping out with a chorus. Every body shared in the emotion
of Anons song, and supplied the story. Anon sang because
spring has come; or winter is gone; because he loves; because
he is hungry, or lustful; or merry. or because he adores
